Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Investigating Transitions in Agricultural Livelihoods: Global Change, Response Diversity, and Local Food Production

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past thirty years, scholars and policymakers have become increasingly concerned with the negative effects of global change on the sustainability of rural livelihoods, both in the United States and around the world. We know from research that economic globalization and the integration of farmers into global commodity chains often has resulted in rising economic dependence and exclusion, food insecurity, and environmental degradation. These dynamics have been particularly damaging to the viability of smallholding family farmers, who nonetheless continue to produce 80 percent of the global food supply. In light of these global challenges, recent scholarship has identified farmer-led transitions toward local food production as a new and sustainable path for rural development. Understanding the factors that promote sustainable transitions to local food production is therefore critical for advancing effective programs and policies that support future rural development efforts. This research will contribute essential support to the PhD training of a female anthropologist. It will also build local research capacities by offering assistantships for three rural youth and will enhance international scientific collaboration. Collaborative engagement strategies will enable findings to inform planning efforts that will facilitate the delivery of more effective support to farming communities. Results will also be disseminated via academic conferences and publications in journals that focus on agriculture, environment, and rural development issues.

Research will be conducted in Dominica, a rural island in the Eastern Caribbean. Dominica is a particularly apt research setting because since the 1990s, agricultural livelihoods there have transitioned from export commodity production to diverse forms of local food production. Although these transitions are associated with positive outcomes including high levels of food security and economic growth, there is currently little known about how farmers have been able to rework local relations and practices of production and exchange. The research will focus on smallholder farming households in three sites that allow for comparison of agricultural livelihoods in distinct social and environmental conditions. Investigators will assess how and why smallholders have responded to changing global conditions by shifting away from export production. Investigators will also assess the impacts of these responses by determining how variable access to resources, markets, and development support reflect diversity in agricultural practices and which of these factors promote sustainable livelihood outcomes for farming families and communities. Investigators will engage in long-term site visits to conduct surveys and interviews, and to participate in and observe agricultural activities. Findings from this research will provide a model for sustainable agricultural transitions; one that can be generalized to other contexts facing similar global dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award enabled the Co-PI, a female graduate in cultural anthropology, to successfully conduct field research for her dissertation project, which investigates the sustainability of livelihood transitions from export agriculture to local food production in Dominica. Over the past 20-30 years, research has confirmed certain global shifts in agriculture. Small-scale family farmers have found it more difficult to survive in global markets, leading many to restructure their production to serve more local and informal markets. While many have considered this trend to be evidence of a decline in the viability of smallholder agriculture, social movements for food sovereignty and some interdisciplinary researchers have identified these transitions as producing positive outcomes that comprise a new pathway for rural development. Yet there have been few studies that investigate how sustainable these types of livelihood transitions actually are for farming households. This project was designed to close this knowledge gap. Field research included comparative, mixed-methods data collection including a gender-disaggregated panel survey of 70 households, participant observation, archival research, GIS mapping of farms, and interviews with experts and government officials. While conducting research, the Co-PI also trained two agricultural extension officers in GIS data collection and analysis. Thus, the project contributed to building research capacity in social science methods and spatial analysis within a developing country.

Results of the research indicate significant spatial, temporal, gender, and class differences in the sustainability of agricultural livelihood transitions in Dominica. This means that smallholder transitions to local food production are not necessarily "bad," but nor are they inherently "good" as current theoretical frameworks and political discourses on food sovereignty frequently suppose. Rather livelihood sustainability is dependent on the complex interaction of place- and position- based specificities that impact individuals, households, and communities in distinct and sometimes surprising ways.

The data produced from this project is being used to write the Co-PI's dissertation (scheduled to be completed by May 2020) and will also result in the publication of multiple journal articles.  Overall, these findings will contribute to a better understanding of agricultural change in the Eastern Caribbean, a region where most farmers have transitioned from export to local and regional food production. It provides evidence of the various criteria individuals, households, and communities require to generate successful, sustainable livelihoods in agriculture. The Co-PI has presented preliminary findings at an international professional meeting of anthropologists. Results have also been shared with farmers' groups as well as the Ministry of Agriculture and the Bureau of Gender Affairs in Dominica, which could help to facilitate the formation of more effective policies and support structures to aid future rural development efforts.
